title: Twitch's stealth vs human reaction time
body:
Human reaction time is around 0.25 sec, i happen to be a tad slow at 0.3, some people are slower, some are faster.

Late game Twitch can get close to, or even hit the 2.5 attack per second limit, which means he fires every 0.4 seconds.

If he fire his first attack from stealth at t=0.0, his second at t=0.4, and his third at t=0.8....

Factoring the average human reaction time and server ping, you have at MOST 0.5 seconds to react and do anything if he can kill you in three attacks, or at worst 0.1 seconds if he crits twice and kills you in two attacks.

Considering he will probably start attacking you from outside your threat zone, and that most projectiles have a delay, and that most CC spells are telegraphed, it means that unless you are tanky......

....  *drumrolls*

Lategame {{champion:29}} has no counterplay.

So, according to you, Twitch should be completely useless in pro play, since they know how to place control wards, right? Oh, wait... He's a top tier pick there. Huh. Go figure. 

Control wards only shut Twitch down if the enemy is incompetent and doesn't know how to play. Your control wards won't last 30 seconds if they're placed where they need to be to spot Twitch, and you _can't_ protect them in those positions. How do you propose to protect a control ward in the middle of a lane? Going straight down a lane while stealthed is very common for Twitch. His team can easily take out any obvious control wards, and a ward in the middle of your team won't have the vision range to do anything for you. Plus, you can very easily get pushed off of it. 

On top of that, dedicating all 5 of your team's control wards (and, at your elo, you're not going to be having 5 control wards on the map at once, anyways - maybe 1 at a time) to try and spot out Twitch in one quadrant of the map means that you are leaving the rest of the map completely in the enemies' control. And "moving the line of vision" every time you change lanes or switch to an objective is rather expensive. Not only can they clear out the wards, they can just decide to move to another area, pressure another lane or objective, etc, where your team has no vision now. 

Your arguments are assuming 2 things - first, that your team is significantly ahead and is able to control the pace of the game and where fights will happen. That is only the case maybe 1/4 of the time, and doesn't influence lane phase at all. Second, that the enemy Twitch is wandering around solo trying to 1v5. Which will _never_ happen unless the Twitch is an idiot. You aren't "intelligently shutting down Twitch through vision control". You're just playing against terrible Twitch players.

TLDR

Considering your arguments, I sincerely hope you are trolling. Can control wards limit Twitch's power? Yeah, definitely. But they most certainly do not "SHUT HIM DOWN", as you claim. There's a reason Twitch has been at a 53-54% winrate for the last year and a half - which increases the higher elo you are. If control wards shut him down, he would be trash in Plat+, and especially pro play, since that's where people actually buy tons of control wards. But that isn't the case. 

Control wards only temporarily limit his pathing while stealthed - but he doesn't _have_ to approach you while stealthed. He is one of the strongest teamfight ADCs in the game, and will annihilate your team if he isn't picked off early. His stealth simply gives him the ability to be an assassin, as well. Control wards help against that, but they aren't _the_ answer to beating him - Twitch isn't like old Akali, where you could just pink ward her shroud and make her useless. 

Just tossing out tons of control wards may work against Bronze/Silver Twitch players who think they're supposed to run around solo and jump out at people, but it doesn't work as well against Twitch players who actually know how to play League with their brains.

He gets revealed early and it is HILARIOUS to see him get CCed early and die.

Reaction time is faster for auditory stimulus (0.17 seconds), and Twitch is hardly quiet when he comes out of stealth (especially if he ults).

Say you have 50 ping, and twitch starts firing at t=0. You should register that Twitch is shooting you at t=0.22 seconds, or t=0.3 seconds if you have the sound off for some reason.

Since, by your own numbers, Twitch will only get his second shot off at t=0.4, the only thing that has "no counterplay" is his very first attack out of stealth.

Generally, a late game Twitch will need about three hits and an E to kill a squishy, meaning a bit less than a second.

So subtract the 0.3 seconds it takes for it to register (worst case), and you have a little more than a half second window to prevent the rat from killing your squishies. That's fast, but not impossibly fast.
